description: A general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and extraterrestrial life; stars, their evolution, and their final state as white dwarfs, neutron stars, or black holes; galaxies, quasars, large structures, background radiation, and big bang cosmology. Elementary algebra and geometry will be used. This course is not recommended for physical-science majors or engineering students.
name: SURVEY OF THE UNIVERSE

values.comments:
This course is a general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and
theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and
cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and
extraterrestrial life. Elementary algebra and geometry is used.
Many students found the subject matter covered in this course to be “fascinating.”
One student remarked that the course “stimulated [his] interest in astronomy.” Overall,
though, students seemed to view the course as a “mixed bag,” with disparities between
the quality of the instructor and interest of the course material, and with the difficulty and
quantity of the coursework.
Most students in the course raved about Professor Devlin, calling him a “fantastic
professor” who was “extremely knowledgeable and eloquent.” Professor Devlin had a
“good sense of humor,” and students seemed to agree that he made “all the difference in
this class.” A few students noted that he “mov[ed] too fast” and that he was “not a great
teacher” and sometimes explained concepts in “unclear, even obtuse ways.” However,
students largely felt that his teaching was excellent and that Professor Devlin provided
“sufficient guidance.”
Overall, students seemed to agree that the course was generally difficult. Many
students were non-science majors who took the course to fulfill general requirements.
However, many students remarked that it required more math than they had thought it
would. Homework and other assignments made up an “appropriate portion of the grade,”
apart from exams. Many students commented that the homework assignments were timeconsuming,
“poorly thought-out and executed” and had limited educational value in
relation to the course. Students generally found the tests to be very difficult. Altogether,
many students agreed that the “workload was a little intense for an intro class,” though
still a “very good general requirement course.” This course is not recommended for
physical-science majors or engineering students. It fulfills the Physical World sector.

This course is a general survey, designed for the non-major, of the facts and
theories of the astronomical universe, from solar system, to stars, to galaxies and
cosmology. Topics include planets, satellites, small objects in the solar system, and
extraterrestrial life. Elementary algebra and geometry is used.
Many students found the subject matter covered in this course to be “fascinating.”
One student remarked that the course “stimulated [his] interest in astronomy.” Overall,
though, students seemed to view the course as a “mixed bag,” with disparities between
the quality of the instructor and interest of the course material, and with the difficulty and
quantity of the coursework.
Most students called Professor Klein a “great instructor” with an “engaging”
teaching style. Many thought he was “one of the best teachers” they’ve had. Professor
Klein made the material accessible, “humorous and interesting.” Professor Klein was also
“more than willing to help outside of class.” Professor Klein was “interested in the
subject matter and could provide real examples from his own life.” However, many
students commented on Professor Klein’s use of cold-calls, which students complained
made the class “nerve-wracking,” especially if they didn’t know the answer.
Overall, students seemed to agree that the course was generally difficult. Many
students were non-science majors who took the course to fulfill general requirements.
However, many students remarked that it required more math than they had thought it
would. Homework and other assignments made up an “appropriate portion of the grade,”
apart from exams. Many students commented that the homework assignments were timeconsuming,
“poorly thought-out and executed” and had limited educational value in
relation to the course. Students generally found the tests to be very difficult. Altogether,
many students agreed that the “workload was a little intense for an intro class,” though
still a “very good general requirement course.” This course is not recommended for
physical-science majors or engineering students. It fulfills the Physical World sector.
